   Differential-Neuts:60.1 %, Lymph:18.5 %, Mono:6.2 %, Eos:14.8 %,
   Fibrinogen:329 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:1.1 mmol/L, Albumin:2.9 g/dL,
   Ca++:9.0 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL, PO4:3.4 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.  Overnight,
   patient has been tachycardic and hypotensive. Lasix drip stopped, given
   total fluid bolus of 750 ml.
   #.Failure to wean from ventilator: Patient has a history of COPD, per
   notes from outside hospital it appears that he was felt to have severe
   COPD and on home O2 and steroids. Patient has failed to wean from
   ventilator; bronchoscopy done at OSH suggested possible
   tracheobronchomalacia. Patient was seen and evaluated by IP on arrival;
   per their notes, they will plan on flexible bronchoscopy once medically
   stabilized. Also in OSH notes there is some report of ?Aspergillus in
   sputum, ?ABPA, but felt not to be cause of his PNA; however, this would
   also fit with eosinophilia. Patient does appear to have significant
   bronchiectasis on CXR which is also a likely explanation for why he may
   be failing to wean from ventilator.
   -IP following, will plan on flex bronchoscopy; patient is now medically
   clear per cardiology
   -ABG to assess current respiratory status on ventilator
   -IgE levels Aspergillus
   #Elevated troponins: Patient was seen and evaluated by Cardiology; per
   the history they obtained from him, they found no evidence of chest
   pain symptoms, and felt that because he is asymptomatic at this time,
   and it is unlikely that his presentation is a true acute coronary
   syndrome requiring emergent cardiac catheterization. Troponins have
   remained stable. Per history that we were able to obtain with a
   translator he has not had any chest pain. One concern is that he may
   have an element of demand ischemia, especially given that he appears to
   be atrial paced at a rate of 90 bpm.
   -Continue ASA
   -Check lipids with AM labs
   -EP consult as patient appears to be atrial paced at rate of 90bpm
   -Beta blocker to help with rate control down to where he has been
   Atrial paced (currently HR 100s-120s)
   -Cardiology has signed off, feel patient stable for any intervention
   that IP wishes.
   .
   #Right eye injection/macular rash around orbit: Patient does describe
   pain in right eye, pain with movement of right eye, difficulty with
   vision out of right eye. Patient was seen by ID & opthomology at OSH,
   initially on Acyclovir, but optho felt that not consistent with
   herpetic eye involvement, most likely chronic conjunctival chemosis.
   Currently no vesicular rash around eye so nothing to biopsy.
   -Ophtho consult in AM as unclear what plan for management of eye was at
   OSH, and patient appears to be experiencing new/worsening symptoms
   # Facial twitching: Appeared as though this may have been a possible
   seizure, though patient did not have clear post-ictal state. Concern
   also for possible air embolus given that episode happened in the
   context of RIJ pull. Will continue to monitor for further signs of
   seizure. Will also need head CT eventually
   -EEG
   -Monitor for signs of seizures
   #Anasarca: Patient was receiving diuresis at OSH; received up to Lasix
   80mg IV BID, then changed to Bumex, which was then d/c'd for
   hypotension. Patient
s weight on admission (presumably dry weight) was
   62 kg. [**Month (only) 51**] be preload dependent given degree of hypotension experienced
   with Lasix.
   -D/c lasix for now as patient appears to be tolerating this poorly,
   becoming tachycardic and hypotensive.
   -Will try to keep patient mildly net negative each day
   #.Leukocytosis: patient was transfered on multiple antibiotics for
   several infections he experienced during 2 months at OSH. At this time,
   he has been taken off all antibiotics, and has been afebrile. However,
   does have mild leukcocytosis (11.8). Will continue to monitor. Sputum
   culture shows  >25 PMNs and <10 epithelial cells/100X field, as well as
   1+ gram neg rods. [**Month (only) 51**] represent colonization with pseudomonas given his
   trach. Will plan to treat if patient becomes febrile. Patient also has
   significant history of diarrhea, so will plan to send C.diff cultures.
   -Monitor fever curve
   -F/u pan culture
   -Stool for C.diff
   -Send galactomannan to assess for possible aspergillosis
   #Eosinophilia: Presented to OSH with eosinophilia; however, it
   subsequently normalized. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to adrenal insufficiency
   (patient was on prednisone for unknown amount of time on arrival to
   OSH, unclear how much this was continued), may be secondary to
   parasitic infection given recent travel to [**Country **]; may be secondary
   to medication.
   -Stool for O&P x3
   -AM cortisol
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,
   betablocker)
   .
   #.Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased ferritin.
   Patient also receiving frequent blood draws which may be contributing
   to drop in HCT as well. Relatively stable this morning (of note,
   patient had multiple attempts at central line placement yesterday).
   (HCT 32.4 yesterday
 29.2 today).
   -Guiaic stools
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   .
   #Elevated alk phos: Alk phos elevated at 236. [**Month (only) 51**] be a continued
   sequelae of shock liver. Will plan to continue to monitor in a few
   days. If continues to be elevated, may consider getting GGT to
   differentiate if this is secondary to increased bone turnover secondary
   to chronic bedbound state.
   -Continue to monitor
   .
   #Hypokalemia: Replete potassium as needed.
   #Hypernatremia: free water flushes via PEG (150 ml q6 hours)
   #Decreased albumin: Measuring prealbumin. Patient most likely
   chronically malnourished given long hospital course. Tube feeds via PEG
   tube, f/u prealbumin.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].
   -Wound care consult
   -Optimize nutrition
   -Frequent repositioning
   .
   FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management with
   .
   ACCESS: Left subclavian in place from OSH. Plan is to d/c left
   subclavian and send tip for culture, PICC placement (if can be done
   over the weekend) vs. LIJ
   CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   .
   DISPOSITION: ICU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2101-11-10**] 11:40 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2101-11-10**] 11:41 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further evaluation and management.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube and is receiving oxygen therapy. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 95%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient is tachycardic, with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and is hypotensive, with a blood pressure of 92/44 mmHg. He has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently paced at a rate of 90 beats per minute.
* Neurological status: The patient is awake and responsive, but has a history of facial twitching, which may have been a possible seizure. He also has a macular rash around his right eye, which may be related to an infection.
* Hematological status: The patient has leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 11.8 x 10^9/L, and eosinophilia, with an eosinophil count of 14.8%. He also has anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.3 g/dL.
* Renal status: The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease and is receiving dialysis.
* Hepatic status: The patient has elevated alkaline phosphatase levels, which may be related to a continued sequelae of shock liver.
* Nutritional status: The patient is receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube and has a history of malnutrition.
* Wound care: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcers on his sacrum and coccyx, and stage IV ulcers on his left ear helix and right post-acromium process.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he may require further management and treatment to prevent respiratory failure.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may be related to his atrial fibrillation and may require further management and treatment.
* Neurological complications: The patient's facial twitching and macular rash around his right eye may be related to an infection and may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Hematological complications: The patient's leukocytosis and eosinophilia may be related to an infection and may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Renal complications: The patient's chronic kidney disease may require further management and treatment.
* Hepatic complications: The patient's elevated alkaline phosphatase levels may be related to a continued sequelae of shock liver and may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Nutritional complications: The patient's malnutrition may require further management and treatment.
* Wound care complications: The patient's decubitus ulcers may require further management and treatment to prevent further complications.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and to improve his overall condition.

   tracheobronchomalacia. Patient was seen and evaluated by IP on arrival;

   sputum, ?ABPA, but felt not to be cause of his PNA; however, this would
   also fit with eosinophilia. Patient does appear to have significant
   bronchiectasis on CXR which is also a likely explanation for why he may
   be failing to wean from ventilator.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a history of COPD, who was admitted to the ICU for possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia. He has been experiencing tachycardia and hypotension overnight, and his Lasix drip was held due to these symptoms. He has also had a brief episode of facial twitching, which was concerning for a possible seizure or air embolus. His labs show elevated troponins, leukocytosis, and eosinophilia, which may be related to his chronic illness, medications, or recent travel. He has multiple comorbidities, including anemia, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and decreased albumin, which may be related to his chronic illness and malnutrition.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Failure to wean from ventilator: The patient's history of COPD and severe bronchiectasis may make it challenging to wean him off the ventilator.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and atrial pacing may indicate cardiac complications, such as demand ischemia or cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and eosinophilia may indicate an underlying infection, such as pneumonia or sepsis.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of diarrhea and elevated alkaline phosphatase may indicate gastrointestinal complications, such as pancreatitis or cholangitis.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition and decreased albumin may increase his risk of developing complications, such as pressure ulcers and infections.
6. Wound care complications: The patient's stage III and IV pressure ulcers may require specialized wound care and may increase his risk of developing infections.
7. Respiratory complications: The patient's history of COPD and bronchiectasis may increase his risk of developing respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's facial twitching and elevated troponins may indicate neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medications as needed.
2. Perform a flexible bronchoscopy to evaluate his airways and rule out any underlying infections.
3. Continue to monitor his respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
4. Evaluate his nutritional status and consider tube feeding or parenteral nutrition if necessary.
5. Provide wound care and pressure ulcer management to prevent further complications.
6. Monitor his gastrointestinal status and consider stool cultures or other diagnostic tests if necessary.
7. Consider ordering additional laboratory tests, such as an EEG or head CT, to evaluate his neurological status.
8. Continue to monitor his infection risk and adjust his antibiotic therapy as needed.

   tracheobronchomalacia. Patient was seen and evaluated by IP on arrival;
   per their notes, they will plan on flexible bronchoscopy once medically
   stabilized. Also in OSH notes there is some report of ?Aspergillus in

   and it is unlikely that his presentation is a true acute coronary
   syndrome requiring emergent cardiac catheterization. Troponins have
   remained stable. Per history that we were able to obtain with a

   #Anasarca: Patient was receiving diuresis at OSH; received up to Lasix

   hypotension. Here, will continue diuresis with a goal UOP of 100ml/hour

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) from another hospital. He has been experiencing tachycardia and hypotension, and his Lasix drip was stopped due to his poor tolerance. He has a history of failure to wean from the ventilator, and a bronchoscopy is planned once he is medically stable. He also has elevated troponins, but his cardiologist has ruled out a true acute coronary syndrome. He has anasarca, leukocytosis, eosinophilia, anemia, elevated alkaline phosphatase, hypokalemia, hypernatremia, and decreased albumin. He has multiple skin ulcers and is receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's failure to wean from the ventilator and his history of COPD increase his risk of respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and atrial pacing may indicate cardiac complications, such as acute coronary syndrome or demand ischemia.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis, eosinophilia, and anemia may indicate an underlying infection, such as sepsis.
4. Malnutrition: The patient's anasarca, anemia, and decreased albumin suggest malnutrition, which may worsen his overall health.
5. Skin ulcers: The patient's multiple skin ulcers may become infected or worsen if not properly managed.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of diarrhea and anasarca may indicate gastrointestinal complications, such as inflammatory bowel disease or malabsorption.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hypokalemia and hypernatremia may indicate electrolyte imbalances, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.
8. Kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and decreased albumin may indicate kidney injury, which can worsen his overall health.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
2. Consider consulting cardiology to further evaluate the patient's cardiac status and potential cardiac complications.
3. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medications as needed to prevent electrolyte imbalances.
4. Continue to manage the patient's skin ulcers and prevent further infection or worsening.
5. Consider consulting gastroenterology to evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal status and potential complications.
6. Monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust his tube feeds as needed to prevent malnutrition.
7. Consider consulting nephrology to evaluate the patient's kidney status and potential complications.

   not to be cause of his PNA; however, this would also fit with
   eosinophilia. Patient does appear to have significant bronchiectasis on
   CXR which is also a likely explanation for why he may be failing to
   wean from ventilator.
   -IP following, will plan on flex bronchoscopy; patient is now medically

   syndrome requiring emergent cardiac catheterization. Troponins have

   have an element of demand ischemia, especially given that he appears to
   be atrial paced at a rate of 90 bpm.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) from another hospital for further evaluation and management.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is mechanically ventilated and has a history of failure to wean from the ventilator. The respiratory therapist is planning to perform a flexible bronchoscopy once the patient is medically stabilized.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has elevated troponins, which were attributed to demand ischemia, and is being treated with aspirin and beta blockers to control his heart rate.
* Neurological status: The patient has facial twitching, which may be a seizure or an air embolus, and is being monitored for further signs of seizure activity.
* Hematological status: The patient has leukocytosis, which is being monitored, and has a history of eosinophilia, which may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency, parasitic infection, or medication.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has diarrhea and is being treated with antibiotics, and has a history of anemia of chronic disease.
* Renal status: The patient has anuria and is being treated with diuretics.
* Nutritional status: The patient is malnourished and is being fed through a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.

The patient's medical team is concerned about the following potential complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further intervention to wean him from the ventilator.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's elevated troponins and demand ischemia may lead to further cardiac complications.
* Neurological complications: The patient's facial twitching and possible seizure activity may lead to further neurological complications.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea and possible C. difficile infection may lead to further gastrointestinal complications.
* Renal complications: The patient's anuria and possible hypotension may lead to further renal complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Further evaluation and management of his respiratory status
* Treatment of his cardiovascular and neurological symptoms
* Monitoring of his gastrointestinal and renal function
* Optimization of his nutritional status
* Management of his wound care and pressure ulcers
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure, presumed to be due to tracheobronchomalacia.
* The patient has undergone several procedures, including tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement, and has been receiving mechanical ventilation.
* The patient's recent laboratory results show:
	+ Elevated troponins, but no evidence of cardiac compromise
	+ Mild leukocytosis, with a sputum culture showing 1+ Gram-negative rods (GNR)
	+ Eosinophilia, which has normalized
	+ Anemia of chronic disease
	+ Elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
	+ Hypokalemia and hypernatremia
	+ Decreased albumin and prealbumin
* The patient has several potential complications, including:
	+ Respiratory failure, which is being managed with mechanical ventilation
	+ Seizure, which is being monitored and treated
	+ Leukocytosis, which may be due to colonization or infection
	+ Anasarca, which is being managed with diuresis
	+ Eosinophilia, which may be due to adrenal insufficiency, parasitic infection, or medication
	+ Anemia, which is likely due to chronic disease and frequent blood draws
	+ Right eye injection and macular rash, which is being managed with ophthalmology consult
	+ Elevated ALP, which may be due to shock liver
	+ Ulcers, which are being managed with wound care consult and optimization of nutrition
* The patient's current medications include:
	+ Ciprofloxacin and cefipime, which were discontinued due to sepsis
	+ Aspirin, which was started due to elevated troponins
	+ Beta blocker, which was started due to tachycardia and hypotension
	+ Lasix, which was discontinued due to hypotension
	+ Bumex, which was discontinued due to hypotension
	+ Prednisone, which was discontinued due to unclear continuation
	+ Tube feeds via PEG tube
	+ Pain management medications
* The patient's current vital signs are:
	+ Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
	+ Heart rate: 117 beats per minute (bpm)
	+ Blood pressure: 114/63 mmHg
	+ Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute
	+ Oxygen saturation: 98%

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, requiring more aggressive management or consideration of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and elevated troponins may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Cardiac compromise: The patient's elevated troponins and tachycardia may indicate cardiac compromise, which could lead to heart failure or arrhythmias.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and elevated ALP may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock.
5. Wound complications: The patient's ulcers may become infected or develop complications, such as osteomyelitis or sepsis.
6. Eye complications: The patient's right eye injection and macular rash may worsen, requiring more aggressive management or consideration of surgical intervention.
7. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's hypokalemia and hypernatremia may lead to electrolyte imbalances, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and consideration of ECMO if necessary.
3. Treat the patient's leukocytosis and elevated troponins with antibiotics and consideration of cardiac catheterization if necessary.
4. Manage the patient's anemia with blood transfusions and consideration of iron supplements.
5. Optimize the patient's nutrition with tube feeds via PEG tube and consideration of parenteral nutrition if necessary.
6. Manage the patient's eye complications with ophthalmology consult and consideration of surgical intervention if necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's electrolyte imbalances and manage them accordingly.
8. Consider consultation with specialists, such as cardiology, gastroenterology, and ophthalmology, to manage the patient's complex medical condition.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including COPD, who was admitted to the ICU for further evaluation and management. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of COPD and was previously intubated and ventilated. He is currently on CPAP/PSV with a FiO2 of 30% and a SpO2 of 99%. His respiratory status is stable, but he requires ongoing respiratory support.
* Seizure: The patient had a brief episode of altered responsiveness with right-sided twitching, which was treated with anticonvulsants. EEG and CT head are pending to further evaluate the episode.
* Elevated Troponins: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, but he does not have a history of cardiac disease or symptoms of myocardial infarction. His cardiac enzymes are stable, and he does not require emergent cardiac catheterization.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has mild leukocytosis, which is trending down. He has a history of diarrhea, and his sputum culture shows two species of GNR. Colonization vs. infection is unclear, and further evaluation is needed.
* Anasarca: The patient has peripheral edema, which is managed with diuretics. He is receiving Lasix 80mg IV BID, but it was held due to hypotension.
* Eosinophilia: The patient has a history of eosinophilia, which has normalized. He has a random cortisol level of 1.8, and concern for adrenal insufficiency exists.
* Anemia: The patient has a stable Hct, and his iron studies are consistent with anemia of chronic disease.
* Right Eye Injection/Macular Orbital Rash: The patient has a chronic conjunctival chemosis, and no vesicular rash around the eye. Ophthalmology consult is planned for Monday.
* Elevated Alk Phos: The patient's alk phosphatase level is elevated at 236. This may be a sequelae of shock liver, and further evaluation is needed.
* Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium level has resolved.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is 146, and he requires free water flushes via PEG to 150ml q4hr.
* Decreased Albumin: The patient's albumin level is decreased, and he is likely chronically malnourished. Tube feeds via PEG tube are ongoing, and prealbumin levels will be monitored.
* Ulcers: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on the sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on the left ear helix. Wound care consult is planned.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he requires ongoing respiratory support. He may require further evaluation and management to optimize his respiratory function.
* Seizure: The patient's seizure episode may be a one-time event, but further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and prevent future episodes.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponin levels and tachycardia may indicate cardiac ischemia or infarction. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and prevent cardiac complications.
* Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and sputum culture results may indicate infection. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and treat the infection appropriately.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's random cortisol level of 1.8 may indicate adrenal insufficiency. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and treat the condition appropriately.
* Malnutrition: The patient's decreased albumin level and chronic malnutrition may indicate a need for further nutritional support and evaluation.
* Pressure ulcers: The patient's stage III and IV pressure ulcers require ongoing wound care and management to prevent further deterioration.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex, and ongoing monitoring and evaluation are needed to prevent medical complications and optimize his care.

Based on the provided progress note, I have summarized the patient's health status and identified potential medical complications that may arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including COPD, tracheobronchomalacia, and previous hospitalizations for multiple complications, including VAP and failure to wean from the ventilator. He was recently transferred to the ICU from another hospital for further evaluation and management.

The patient experienced a brief episode of altered responsiveness with right-sided twitching, which was initially concerning for seizure or air embolism. An EEG is pending to rule out seizure activity. He also has elevated troponins, which may be related to demand ischemia in the setting of tachycardia and hypotension. The patient has a history of eosinophilia, which has normalized, and a random cortisol level of 1.8, which may indicate adrenal insufficiency.

The patient has several comorbidities, including anemia, leukocytosis, and hypoalbuminemia, which may be related to chronic disease or malnutrition. He also has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, which require wound care and frequent repositioning.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of COPD and tracheobronchomalacia increases the risk of respiratory failure, especially with continued ventilator dependence.
2. Seizure activity: The patient's recent episode of altered responsiveness and twitching may indicate seizure activity, which requires ongoing monitoring and management.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and tachycardia may indicate cardiac ischemia or infarction, which requires close monitoring and consideration of further cardiac evaluation.
4. Infection: The patient's history of VAP and colonization with GNRs increases the risk of infection, particularly with central line placement and continued antibiotic use.
5. Anemia and malnutrition: The patient's anemia and hypoalbuminemia may worsen if not addressed, leading to decreased tissue perfusion and increased risk of complications.
6. Pressure ulcers: The patient's stage III and IV decubitus ulcers require ongoing wound care and frequent repositioning to prevent further deterioration.
7. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's low cortisol level may indicate adrenal insufficiency, which requires ongoing monitoring and management.

**Plan:**

Based on the patient's current status, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider flexible bronchoscopy once medically stabilized.
2. Manage the patient's seizure activity with ongoing EEG monitoring and anticonvulsant therapy as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider further cardiac evaluation if symptoms worsen.
4. Implement infection prevention measures, including central line placement and antibiotic stewardship.
5. Address the patient's anemia and malnutrition with iron studies, blood transfusions, and nutritional support as needed.
6. Provide ongoing wound care and frequent repositioning for the patient's pressure ulcers.
7. Consider further evaluation and management of adrenal insufficiency, including corticosteroid replacement therapy if necessary.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and possible tracheobronchomalacia.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, with a decrease in respiratory rate and improvement in oxygen saturation. However, he remains on mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy tube in place.

The patient has also developed several complications, including:

1. Elevated troponins: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, but cardiac catheterization is not recommended at this time. The patient is being treated with beta blockers to control his heart rate and rhythm.
2. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisone stimulation test was positive, indicating adrenal insufficiency. He is being treated with prednisone 5mg PO daily.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, but trending down. He has a mild fever and a positive sputum culture for two species of Gram-negative rods.
4. Anasarca: The patient has developed edema, which is being managed with diuretics.
5. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophil count is elevated, but trending down. This may be related to parasitic infection or a drug reaction.
6. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, likely due to chronic disease and iron deficiency.
7. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a painful eye and difficulty with vision, which is being managed with pain medication and an ophthalmology consult.
8. Elevated alkaline phosphatase: The patient's alkaline phosphatase level is elevated, likely due to liver dysfunction.
9. Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium level is low, but has resolved.
10. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, and his free water flushes have been increased to 250cc q4.
11. Decreased albumin: The patient's albumin level is low, likely due to chronic malnutrition.
12. Ulcers: The patient has developed stage III and IV decubitus ulcers, which are being managed with wound care and frequent repositioning.

The patient's medications include:

* Furosemide (Lasix) 5mg/hour IV
* Heparin sodium (Prophylaxis) 2101-11-14 04:00 AM
* Metoprolol 5mg PO daily
* Prednisone 5mg PO daily
* Acyclovir (discontinued)
* PPI (discontinued)
* Diuretics (discontinued)
* Beta blockers (discontinued)

The patient's plan includes:

* Flexible bronchoscopy once medically stabilized
* Follow-up IgE levels for Aspergillus
* Formal airway CT today
* Wean from ventilator
* Continue ASA
* Increase Metoprolol
* Monitor fever curve
* Optimize nutrition
* Frequent repositioning
* Wound care consult
* Pain management
* DVT prophylaxis with Heparin SQ
* Bowel regimen
* PICC line care

The patient's code status is full code, and his primary contact person is his daughter, who is aware of his wishes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and has undergone tracheostomy and PEG placement. He is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube and is receiving oxygen therapy.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has tachycardia and hypotension, with elevated troponins, suggesting possible demand ischemia. He is receiving beta blocker therapy.
* Neurological status: The patient had a presumed seizure episode, and EEG leads are coming off. He is awaiting further neuroconsultation.
* Infectious disease: The patient has a history of colonization with GNR, and his sputum culture shows two species of GNR. He has also had a central line infection, which has been treated. He is awaiting further cultures.
* Endocrine status: The patient has adrenal insufficiency, which was confirmed by cosyntropin stimulation test. He is receiving prednisone therapy.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has anemia, which is likely due to chronic disease. He has also had a history of diarrhea, and his C. diff test is negative.
* Renal status: The patient is receiving diuretic therapy and has a history of hypokalemia, which has resolved.
* Hematological status: The patient has leukocytosis, which is trending down.
* Nutritional status: The patient is receiving tube feeds via PEG tube.
* Wound status: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on left ear helix.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is fragile, and he may experience further respiratory decline.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypotension may lead to further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
* Infectious complications: The patient's history of colonization with GNR and his central line infection increase his risk of developing further infections.
* Endocrine complications: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may lead to further complications, such as hypotension or electrolyte imbalances.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of diarrhea and anemia may lead to further gastrointestinal complications, such as malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances.
* Renal complications: The patient's diuretic therapy may lead to further electrolyte imbalances or renal dysfunction.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical issues, and close monitoring and management are essential to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and possible tracheobronchomalacia.
* The patient has been experiencing tachycardia, hypotension, and elevated troponins, which may indicate demand ischemia.
* He has a history of diarrhea and colonization with two species of Gram-negative rods, and his central line was pulled due to colonization.
* The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers and a healed pressure ulcer.
* He is receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube and has a PICC line.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's COPD and tracheobronchomalacia may lead to ongoing respiratory failure, which requires close monitoring and possible flexible bronchoscopy.
2. **Seizure:** The patient's presumed seizure may indicate a neurological complication, which requires further evaluation with EEG and possible consultation with a neurologist.
3. **Cardiac Complications:** The patient's elevated troponins, tachycardia, and hypotension may indicate cardiac complications, such as demand ischemia or cardiomyopathy, which requires close monitoring and possible consultation with a cardiologist.
4. **Infection:** The patient's colonization with Gram-negative rods and yeast may indicate ongoing infection, which requires close monitoring and possible antibiotics.
5. **Malnutrition:** The patient's chronic malnutrition may worsen his condition, which requires optimization of nutrition and possible consultation with a nutritionist.
6. **Wound Care:** The patient's stage III and IV decubitus ulcers require close monitoring and possible wound care consult.
7. **Anasarca:** The patient's fluid overload may worsen his condition, which requires close monitoring and possible diuresis.
8. **Eosinophilia:** The patient's eosinophilia may indicate an allergic reaction or parasitic infection, which requires further evaluation and possible consultation with an allergist or infectious disease specialist.

In summary, the patient is at risk for ongoing respiratory failure, seizure, cardiac complications, infection, malnutrition, wound care issues, anasarca, and eosinophilia. Close monitoring and possible consultation with various specialists are necessary to manage these potential complications and optimize the patient's care.

Based on the progress note, I summarize the patient's current status as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient has a history of COPD, bronchiectasis, and tracheobronchomalacia. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy tube in place. His respiratory status has been stable, with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 100%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has elevated troponins, which are stable, and is being treated with beta blockers. He has a history of tachycardia and hypotension, which may be related to demand ischemia.
* Neurological: The patient has had a presumed seizure, but no further episodes have occurred. He is awaiting EEG results.
* Hematology: The patient has leukocytosis, which is trending down, and anemia, which is likely due to chronic disease.
* Infectious Disease: The patient has a history of diarrhea and has been colonized with two species of Gram-negative rods. His urine culture is positive for yeast.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of C. difficile-negative diarrhea and is being treated with tube feeds via PEG tube.
* Skin: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers on his sacrum and left ear helix, respectively.
* Endocrine: The patient has eosinophilia, which is currently stable, and is being monitored for adrenal insufficiency.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he may continue to require mechanical ventilation and may be at risk for respiratory failure if his condition worsens.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient's elevated troponins and history of tachycardia and hypotension may indicate cardiac ischemia or infarction.
* Neurological complications: The patient's history of seizure and pending EEG results may indicate a neurological disorder.
* Infectious complications: The patient's colonization with Gram-negative rods and positive urine culture for yeast may indicate a risk of infection.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of diarrhea and tube feeds via PEG tube may indicate a risk of gastrointestinal complications.
* Skin complications: The patient's decubitus ulcers may become infected or worsen if not properly treated.
* Endocrine complications: The patient's eosinophilia and history of adrenal insufficiency may indicate a risk of endocrine complications.

Based on the patient's current status and potential medical complications, I recommend the following:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his mechanical ventilation as needed.
* Continue to treat the patient's cardiovascular symptoms with beta blockers and monitor his troponins.
* Monitor the patient's neurological status and await EEG results.
* Continue to monitor the patient's infectious disease status and adjust his treatment as needed.
* Continue to treat the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms with tube feeds via PEG tube and monitor his bowel regimen.
* Continue to monitor the patient's skin status and adjust his wound care as needed.
* Monitor the patient's endocrine status and adjust his treatment as needed.

I also recommend the following:

* Consider performing a flexible bronchoscopy to evaluate the patient's tracheobronchomalacia.
* Consider performing a cardiac catheterization to evaluate the patient's cardiac status.
* Consider performing a lumbar puncture to evaluate the patient's cerebrospinal fluid.
* Consider performing a skin biopsy to evaluate the patient's skin lesions.
* Consider performing a gastrointestinal endoscopy to evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal tract.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old man with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for respiratory failure and possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia. He has a history of multiple complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), failure to wean from the ventilator, and tracheostomy placement. The patient has also been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency, leukocytosis, anasarca, eosinophilia, anemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels.

The patient's current condition is stable, but he remains at risk for various medical complications, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD is poorly controlled, and he is still dependent on the ventilator.
2. Seizure: The patient had a presumed seizure, and EEG and CT head scans are pending.
3. Elevated troponins: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, and he is at risk for demand ischemia.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency and is receiving treatment with prednisone.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and he is at risk for infection.
6. Anasarca: The patient has significant edema, which is being treated with diuretics.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophil count is elevated, and he is at risk for parasitic infection or drug reaction.
8. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and he is at risk for anemia of chronic disease.
9. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a painful eye condition that is being treated with prednisone.
10. Elevated alkaline phosphatase: The patient's alkaline phosphatase level is elevated, and he is at risk for liver dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD can worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Seizure: The patient can have another seizure, which can lead to further complications.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins can indicate cardiac ischemia or infarction.
4. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and anasarca make him at risk for infection.
5. Adrenal crisis: The patient's adrenal insufficiency can lead to adrenal crisis if not properly treated.
6. Malnutrition: The patient's anemia and low albumin level indicate malnutrition, which can worsen his overall condition.
7. Wound complications: The patient's decubitus ulcers can worsen, leading to further complications.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hypernatremia and hypokalemia can lead to electrolyte imbalance.
9. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated alkaline phosphatase level can indicate liver dysfunction.
10. Parasitic infection: The patient's eosinophilia and travel history make him at risk for parasitic infection.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including COPD, who was recently hospitalized at another facility (OSH) for multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from the ventilator, and trach and PEG placement. He was sent to the current hospital for IP assessment for possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: He is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube, with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 100%.
* Cardiovascular status: He has elevated troponins, which are stable, and is on beta blocker therapy. He has a history of tachycardia and hypotension.
* Neurological status: He had a presumed seizure, and an EEG is pending. He also has a macular rash around his orbit and right eye conjunctiva injection.
* Infectious disease: He has a history of diarrhea and was found to have colonization with two species of GNR in his sputum. He also has a history of C. diff negative stool culture.
* Endocrine status: He has adrenal insufficiency, as confirmed by cosyntropin stimulation test.
* Gastrointestinal status: He has anemia of chronic disease, and his iron studies are consistent with this diagnosis.
* Nutritional status: He is malnourished and is receiving tube feeds via PEG tube.
* Wound status: He has stage III decubitus ulcer on his sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on his left ear helix.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and history of tachycardia and hypotension may indicate cardiac ischemia or infarction.
* Neurological complications: The patient's presumed seizure and macular rash around his orbit may indicate a neurological disorder or infection.
* Infectious complications: The patient's history of diarrhea and colonization with GNR in his sputum may indicate a new infection.
* Endocrine complications: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may require ongoing treatment and monitoring.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's anemia of chronic disease may require ongoing monitoring and treatment.
* Nutritional complications: The patient's malnutrition may require ongoing tube feeds and nutritional support.
* Wound complications: The patient's decubitus ulcers may require ongoing wound care and management.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Flex bronchoscopy to evaluate tracheobronchomalacia
* Ophthalmology consult to evaluate macular rash around his orbit
* Infectious disease consult to evaluate colonization with GNR in his sputum
* Endocrine consult to evaluate adrenal insufficiency
* Gastrointestinal consult to evaluate anemia of chronic disease
* Wound care consult to evaluate decubitus ulcers
* Nutrition consult to evaluate malnutrition
* Pain management to manage patient's pain
* Frequent repositioning to prevent decubitus ulcers
* DVT prophylaxis with heparin SQ
* Bowel regimen to manage patient's bowel habits
* Code status: Full code.

   -f/u IgE levels Aspergillus
   - wean from vent
   #. Seizure: Presumed seizure since he was unresponsive and twitching.
   No further episodes. EEG initial report shows no epileptiform activity,
   diffuse slowing consistent with encephalopathy
   - EEG pending
   - CT head
   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, feel does
   not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin elevated yesterday to 0.59, metoprolol was
   increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia. Also may have poor
   renal function without elevated creatinine in the setting of very
   little muscle mass. Continues tachycardic, slightly improved.
   -Continue ASA
   -When HR decreased so that pacer spikes can be viewed consider EP
   consult
   -Check troponin again and EKG
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   -If troponins trending up will get cardiology consult
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   #. Leukocytosis: Trending down still. Patient febrile yesterday to
   101.1, pancultured. No growth to date from any blood or urine.  Sputum
   culture + for pseudomonas; sputum gram stain from yesterday continues +
   for GNR. Colonization vs infection. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   -SC tip pending
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Patient was receiving diuresis at OSH; received up to
   Lasix 80mg IV BID, then changed to Bumex, which was then d/c'd for
   hypotension. Patient
s weight on admission to OSH (presumably dry
   weight) was 62 kg.  No occlusive DVT in upper extremities. On lasix gtt
   for most of yesterday, net negative significantly but then became
   hypotensive.
   -Restart lasix gtt this am, very gentle diuresis
   - Will try to keep patient mildly net negative each day (goal for
   today: -500mL)
   #. Eosinophilia: Presented to OSH with eosinophilia which normalized,
   then at presentation to [**Hospital1 19**] at 14%. Now trending down to 8% on
   prednisone, most likely eosinophilia secondary to adrenal
   insufficiency. Recent travel to [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be secondary to
   parasitic infection; however, O&P neg TD.  Also concern for drug
   reaction
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,
   betablocker)
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Patient does describe pain
   in right eye, pain with movement, and difficulty with vision. Patient
   was seen by ID & opthomology at OSH, initially on Acyclovir, but optho
   felt that not consistent with herpetic eye involvement, most likely
   chronic conjunctival chemosis. Currently no vesicular rash around eye
   so nothing to biopsy.
   -Consider ophtho consult
   #Decreased albumin: Measuring prealbumin. Patient most likely
   chronically malnourished given long hospital course. Tube feeds via PEG
   tube, f/u prealbumin.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].
   -Wound care consult
   -Optimize nutrition
   -Frequent repositioning

Summary:

The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including COPD, who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure. He has been experiencing tachycardia, hypotension, and elevated troponin levels, which may be indicative of demand ischemia. The patient has also been experiencing fever, leukocytosis, and anasarca, which may be related to an underlying infection. He has been receiving treatment for adrenal insufficiency, and his eosinophilia has normalized with prednisone therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his underlying COPD, bronchiectasis, and possible tracheobronchomalacia.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponin levels and tachycardia may indicate demand ischemia, which could lead to cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Infection: The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and anasarca may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis or organ failure.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may worsen if not properly managed, leading to adrenal crisis or other complications.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's chronic malnutrition may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as decreased immune function or impaired wound healing.
6. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's decubitus ulcers may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as infection or organ failure.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's bronchiectasis and possible tracheobronchomalacia may increase his risk of developing pneumonia.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of diarrhea and possible C. diff infection may increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or perforation.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current condition is unstable, and he requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and infectious complications. The patient's adrenal insufficiency, malnutrition, and decubitus ulcers require ongoing management and optimization. The patient's family should be informed of his condition and the potential complications that may arise.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was recently hospitalized at OSH for multiple complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), failure to wean from the ventilator, and tracheostomy. He was transferred to the current hospital for further evaluation and possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 342 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O. His oxygen saturation is 97% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 30%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has elevated troponins, which may be due to demand ischemia or poor renal function. His heart rate is 103 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 88/44 mmHg.
* Neurological status: The patient had a presumed seizure, and an electroencephalogram (EEG) is pending. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is not specified.
* Hematological status: The patient has leukocytosis, trending down, with a white blood cell count of 10.9 x 10^9/L. His eosinophilia is 8%, which may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency or a parasitic infection.
* Renal status: The patient has a creatinine level of 104 mg/dL, which may be due to poor renal function or dehydration.
* Nutritional status: The patient is receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube and has a significant history of diarrhea.
* Wound care: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on the sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on the left ear helix.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and he may require further interventions to improve his oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's elevated troponins and tachycardia may indicate demand ischemia or poor renal function, which may lead to further cardiovascular complications.
3. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and eosinophilia may indicate an underlying infection, which needs to be investigated and treated promptly.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's eosinophilia and adrenal insufficiency may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent adrenal crisis.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's significant history of diarrhea and malnutrition may require further nutritional support and optimization.
6. Wound care complications: The patient's decubitus ulcers may require further debridement and dressing changes to prevent infection and promote healing.

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to address his underlying infections, adrenal insufficiency, and malnutrition.

* Cardiovascular status: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, and he has a history of tachycardia and hypotension. His blood pressure is 88/44 mmHg, and his heart rate is 103 beats per minute.
* Hematological status: The patient has leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 10.9 x 10^9/L. He also has anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 9.1 g/dL.
* Renal function: The patient's creatinine level is 0.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 29 mg/dL.
* Liver function: The patient's alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST) levels are elevated, with values of 17 and 23 U/L, respectively.
* Infectious disease: The patient has a history of Aspergillus in his sputum and is suspected of having allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). He also has a central line infection, which is being treated with antibiotics.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has a history of diarrhea and is receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and he may require further interventions to improve his oxygenation and ventilation.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponin levels and history of tachycardia and hypotension suggest that he may be at risk for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
* Infection: The patient has a history of central line infection and may be at risk for further infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and sepsis.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of diarrhea and receipt of tube feeds may put him at risk for gastrointestinal complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and bowel obstruction.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if he continues to have bleeding or if his bone marrow function is compromised.
* Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be a sign of an underlying condition, such as parasitic infection or allergic reaction, which needs to be investigated and treated.

In summary, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a complex medical history and multiple ongoing medical issues. He requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
   #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  Bronch at OSH with
   ?tracheobronchomalacia.  From OSH ?Aspergillus in sputum, ?ABPA. Per
   family report, patient using home O2 for less than one month prior to
   going to hospital, seems he was not that limited by COPD prior to most
   recent hospitalization. CT showed b/l pleural effusions, small/mod on
   right, small on left, diffuse mild bronchial wall thickening and small
   clusters of centrilobular nodules and peribronchovascular ground glass
   opacities suggesting recent infection/inflammation or possibly
   aspiration. No radiologic evidence of TBM.
   -IP following
   -f/u IgE levels Aspergillus
   - wean from vent
   #. Seizure: Presumed seizure since he was unresponsive and twitching.
   No further episodes. EEG initial report shows no epileptiform activity,
   diffuse slowing consistent with encephalopathy
   - EEG pending
   - CT head
   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, feel does
   not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin elevated yesterday to 0.59, metoprolol was
   increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia. Continues
   tachycardic, slightly improved.
   -Continue ASA
   -When HR decreased so that pacer spikes can be viewed consider EP
   consult
   -Check troponin again and EKG
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   #. Leukocytosis: Trending down still. Patient febrile yesterday to
   101.1, pancultured. No growth to date from any blood or urine.  Sputum
   culture + for pseudomonas; sputum gram stain from yesterday continues +
   for GNR. Colonization vs infection. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   -SC tip pending
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Patient was receiving diuresis at OSH; received up to
   Lasix 80mg IV BID, then changed to Bumex, which was then d/c'd for
   hypotension. Patient
s weight on admission to OSH (presumably dry
   weight) was 62 kg.  No occlusive DVT in upper extremities. On lasix gtt
   for most of yesterday, net negative significantly but then became
   hypotensive.
   -Restart lasix gtt this am, very gentle diuresis
   - Will try to keep patient mildly net negative each day
   #. Eosinophilia: Presented to OSH with eosinophilia which normalized,
   then at presentation to [**Hospital1 19**] at 14%. Now trending down to 8% on
   prednisone, most likely  eosinophilia secondary to adrenal
   insufficiency. Recent travel to [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be secondary to
   parasitic infection; however, O&P neg TD.  Also concern for drug
   reaction
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,
   betablocker)
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Patient does describe pain
   in right eye, pain with movement, and difficulty with vision. Patient
   was seen by ID & opthomology at OSH, initially on Acyclovir, but optho
   felt that not consistent with herpetic eye involvement, most likely
   chronic conjunctival chemosis. Currently no vesicular rash around eye
   so nothing to biopsy.
   -Consider ophtho consult
   #Decreased albumin: Measuring prealbumin. Patient most likely
   chronically malnourished given long hospital course. Tube feeds via PEG
   tube, f/u prealbumin.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].
   -Wound care consult
   -Optimize nutrition
   -Frequent repositioning
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, and sent from OSH for IP assessment for possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient has COPD and was unable to wean from the ventilator at OSH. He has bronchiectasis and bronchial wall thickening on CT scan, suggesting recent infection or inflammation.
* Seizure: The patient had a presumed seizure, which was unresponsive and twitching. The EEG initial report shows no epileptiform activity, but further testing is pending.
* Elevated troponins: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, and cardiology recommends medical management. The patient is at risk for demand ischemia due to tachycardia and hypotension.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has a positive cortisotropin syn test, and is receiving prednisone 5mg PO daily.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has a trending down leukocytosis, and is febrile with a temperature of 101.1. He has a history of diarrhea and C. diff negative.
* Anasarca: The patient has edema, which was managed with diuresis at OSH. He is currently receiving a gentle diuresis.
* Eosinophilia: The patient has a history of eosinophilia, which has normalized. He is receiving prednisone for adrenal insufficiency.
* Anemia: The patient has stable hemoglobin levels, likely due to anemia of chronic disease.
* Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has pain and difficulty with vision in his right eye, and was seen by ophthalmology at OSH. He has chronic conjunctival chemosis.
* Decreased albumin: The patient has low albumin levels, likely due to chronic malnutrition. He is receiving tube feeds via PEG tube.
* Ulcers: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on left ear helix.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient may require further respiratory support, such as non-invasive ventilation or intubation.
* Seizure: The patient may require further anticonvulsant therapy or electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring.
* Elevated troponins: The patient may require further cardiac evaluation, such as echocardiogram or cardiac catheterization.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient may require further glucocorticoid therapy or stress dose steroids.
* Leukocytosis: The patient may require further antibiotic therapy or treatment for possible infection.
* Anasarca: The patient may require further diuresis or fluid management.
* Eosinophilia: The patient may require further monitoring or treatment for possible allergic reactions.
* Anemia: The patient may require further transfusion therapy or iron supplementation.
* Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient may require further ophthalmology evaluation or treatment.
* Decreased albumin: The patient may require further nutrition support or albumin replacement therapy.
* Ulcers: The patient may require further wound care or treatment for possible infection.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the following plan of care is recommended:

* Continue respiratory support, including non-invasive ventilation or intubation as needed.
* Continue anticonvulsant therapy and EEG monitoring for seizure prophylaxis.
* Continue cardiac evaluation, including echocardiogram or cardiac catheterization as needed.
* Continue glucocorticoid therapy or stress dose steroids for adrenal insufficiency.
* Continue antibiotic therapy or treatment for possible infection.
* Continue diuresis or fluid management for anasarca.
* Continue monitoring or treatment for possible allergic reactions.
* Continue transfusion therapy or iron supplementation for anemia.
* Continue ophthalmology evaluation or treatment for right eye injection/macular orbital rash.
* Continue nutrition support or albumin replacement therapy for decreased albumin.
* Continue wound care or treatment for possible infection for ulcers.
* Screen for rehab later this week.

 PLEURAL EFFUSION, CHRONIC

   WITHOUT ACUTE EXACERBATION

 HYPERNATREMIA (HIGH SODIUM)
 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 .H/O RESPIRATORY FAILURE, CHRONIC
 .H/O HYPOTENSION (NOT SHOCK)
 ALTERATION IN NUTRITION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
 IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
   #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  Bronch at OSH with
   ?tracheobronchomalacia. . CT showed b/l pleural effusions, small/mod on
   right, small on left, diffuse mild bronchial wall thickening and small
   clusters of centrilobular nodules and peribronchovascular ground glass
   opacities suggesting recent infection/inflammation or possibly
   aspiration. Most likely secondary to previous VAP at OSH. No radiologic
   evidence of TBM  From OSH ? Aspergillus in sputum, ?ABPA. Per family
   report, patient using home O2 for less than one month prior to going to
   hospital, seems he was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent
   hospitalization.
   -IP following, if definitively no stenting will inform pulmonologist at
   OSH
   -f/u IgE levels Aspergillus
   - wean from vent
   #. Seizure: Presumed seizure since he was unresponsive and twitching.
   No further episodes. EEG initial report shows no epileptiform activity,
   diffuse slowing consistent with encephalopathy
   - EEG pending
   - CT head
   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, feel does
   not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin elevated yesterday to 0.59, metoprolol was
   increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia. Also may have poor
   renal function without elevated creatinine in the setting of very
   little muscle mass. Continues tachycardic, slightly improved.
   -Continue ASA
   -When HR decreased so that pacer spikes can be viewed consider EP
   consult
   -Check troponin again and EKG
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   -If troponins trending up will get cardiology consult
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   #. Leukocytosis: Trending down still. Patient febrile yesterday to
   101.1, pancultured. No growth to date from any blood or urine.  Sputum
   culture + for pseudomonas; sputum gram stain from yesterday continues +
   for GNR. Colonization vs infection. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   -SC tip pending
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Patient was receiving diuresis at OSH; received up to
   Lasix 80mg IV BID, then changed to Bumex, which was then d/c'd for
   hypotension. Patient
s weight on admission to OSH (presumably dry
   weight) was 62 kg.  No occlusive DVT in upper extremities. On lasix gtt
   for most of yesterday, net negative significantly but then became
   hypotensive.
   -Restart lasix gtt this am, very gentle diuresis
   - Will try to keep patient mildly net negative each day (goal for
   today: -500mL)
   #. Eosinophilia: Presented to OSH with eosinophilia which normalized,
   then at presentation to [**Hospital1 19**] at 14%. Now trending down to 8% on
   prednisone, most likely eosinophilia secondary to adrenal
   insufficiency. Recent travel to [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be secondary to
   parasitic infection; however, O&P neg TD.  Also concern for drug
   reaction
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,
   betablocker)
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Patient does describe pain
   in right eye, pain with movement, and difficulty with vision. Patient
   was seen by ID & opthomology at OSH, initially on Acyclovir, but optho
   felt that not consistent with herpetic eye involvement, most likely
   chronic conjunctival chemosis. Currently no vesicular rash around eye
   so nothing to biopsy.
   -Consider ophtho consult
   #Decreased albumin: Measuring prealbumin. Patient most likely
   chronically malnourished given long hospital course. Tube feeds via PEG
   tube, f/u prealbumin.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].
   -Wound care consult
   -Optimize nutrition
   -Frequent repositioning
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management with
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: ICU, screen for rehab later this week

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, and a recent hospitalization for respiratory failure. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation in the ICU. His recent laboratory results show elevated troponins, leukocytosis, and eosinophilia. He has also developed anasarca, likely due to fluid overload, and has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and bronchiectasis make him prone to respiratory failure, and his recent hospitalization for respiratory failure increases the risk of readmission.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and eosinophilia may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and tachycardia may indicate cardiac ischemia or infarction, which could lead to cardiac complications.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's eosinophilia and anasarca may be related to adrenal insufficiency, which could lead to further complications.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's chronic malnutrition and anasarca increase the risk of further complications, including wound infections and delayed healing.
6. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's stage III and IV decubitus ulcers increase the risk of further complications, including infection and sepsis.
7. Fluid overload: The patient's anasarca and fluid overload increase the risk of further complications, including cardiac failure and respiratory distress.
8. Aspiration: The patient's inability to protect his airway increases the risk of aspiration, which could lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to support the patient's respiratory function.
2. Monitor the patient's troponins and cardiac rhythm to assess for cardiac complications.
3. Manage the patient's fluid status to prevent further fluid overload and anasarca.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's leukocytosis and eosinophilia to assess for underlying infections.
5. Consider consulting with a wound care specialist to optimize the patient's wound care and prevent further complications.
6. Consider consulting with a nutritionist to optimize the patient's nutrition and prevent further malnutrition.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider consulting with a cardiologist to assess for cardiac complications.
8. Consider consulting with an infectious disease specialist to assess for underlying infections and sepsis.
