   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
   #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  Bronch at OSH with
   ?tracheobronchomalacia, but the CT here showed only findings suggestive
   of infection and no TBM.   Notes from OSH repeatedly bring up ?
   Aspergillus in sputum, ?ABPA, but not seen on testing. Per family
   report, patient using home O2 for less than one month prior to going to
   hospital, seems he was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent
   hospitalization.
   -IP does not want to stent.  We will discuss this with his OSH
   pulmonologist.
   - He appears euvolemic on exam.  We should titrate his lasix with goal
   being even I/O
s today.
   -f/u IgE levels Aspergillus
   - wean from vent as much as possible.  Should get trial of trach mask
   today.
   #. Seizure: One morning had what appeared to be a seizure since he was
   unresponsive and twitching.  No further episodes. EEG initial report
   shows no epileptiform activity, diffuse slowing consistent with
   encephalopathy .  If this recurs we could check a CT head.
   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, felt he
   did not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to 0.61, metoprolol
   was increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia.  Could have
   poor renal function without elevated creatinine in the setting of very
   little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Consult EP with possibility of slowing pacing to allow for more
   effective beta blockade.
   -Check troponin again and EKG
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   -If troponins trending up will get cardiology consult
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   - Consult endocrinology for further management.
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile with slowly improving leukocytosis.  Has
   had yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely
   colonizers. Patient also has significant history of diarrhea, C. diff
   neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.
   - Goal today is even to slightly negative with lasix prn.
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,
   betablocker)
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Decreased albumin: Measuring prealbumin. Patient most likely
   chronically malnourished given long hospital course. Tube feeds via PEG
   tube.  Prealbumin is slightly depressed, but not extremely low,
   suggesting he is receiving adequate nutrition now.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: ICU, screen for rehab later this week

Summary:

The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, and tracheobronchomalacia. He was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and was dependent on a ventilator. His current vital signs include a temperature of 37.5°C, heart rate of 95 bpm, blood pressure of 115/54 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. He has a pleural effusion, chronic anemia, rash, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) without acute exacerbation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating possible myocardial infarction or demand ischemia. His electrocardiogram (ECG) shows no signs of acute coronary syndrome. He has also been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency and is receiving treatment with prednisone.

The patient's physical examination reveals signs of chronic malnutrition, including decreased muscle mass and edema. He has a stage III decubitus ulcer on his sacrum/coccyx and a stage IV ulcer on his left ear helix. He is receiving tube feeds via a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube and is being monitored for electrolyte and fluid disorders.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and tracheobronchomalacia increase his risk of respiratory failure. His dependence on a ventilator and the presence of a pleural effusion also contribute to this risk.
2. Myocardial infarction or demand ischemia: The patient's elevated troponin levels suggest possible myocardial infarction or demand ischemia. His tachycardia and hypotension may also indicate poor cardiac function.
3. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency may lead to adrenal crisis, which can be life-threatening if not treated promptly.
4. Electrolyte and fluid disorders: The patient's chronic malnutrition and electrolyte imbalances increase his risk of developing electrolyte and fluid disorders.
5. Wound infections: The patient's stage III and stage IV decubitus ulcers increase his risk of developing wound infections, which can lead to sepsis and other complications.
6. Seizures: The patient's history of seizures and his elevated troponin levels suggest that he may be at risk for further seizures.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's chronic malnutrition may lead to malnutrition-related complications, such as weakness, fatigue, and impaired wound healing.
8. Pressure ulcers: The patient's chronic malnutrition and immobility increase his risk of developing pressure ulcers, which can lead to wound infections and other complications.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue monitoring his respiratory status, cardiac function, and electrolyte and fluid balance. He should also be closely monitored for signs of adrenal insufficiency, wound infections, and malnutrition-related complications.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
   #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   -IP does not want to stent.  We will discuss this with his OSH
   pulmonologist.
   - He appears euvolemic on exam.  Goal yesterday was even, but patient
   was positive yesterday. Negative this AM.
   - wean from vent as much as possible.  Trial of trach mask went well,
   but then needed some pressure support
   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, felt he
   did not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to 0.61, Metoprolol
   was increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia.  Could have
   poor renal function without elevated creatinine in the setting of very
   little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs.
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile.  Has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine
   and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.  Lasix given overnight
   made slightly negative this AM.
   - Goal today is even to slightly negative with lasix prn.
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: Rehab as soon as bed available ?today

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, and chronic pleural effusion. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with respiratory failure and was found to have elevated troponins, indicating possible demand ischemia. He also has signs of adrenal insufficiency, which was confirmed by a corticotropin stimulation test.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is on a tracheostomy tube with CPAP/PSV ventilation and is tolerating it well. His SpO2 is 97%.
* Cardiovascular: His troponins are persistently elevated, and he has a history of tachycardia and hypotension. He is receiving metoprolol to manage his heart rate.
* Endocrine: He has adrenal insufficiency and is receiving cortisone therapy.
* Renal: His creatinine is normal, but he has mild anemia and elevated troponins, which may indicate poor renal function.
* Hematological: He has leukocytosis and eosinophilia, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions.
* Gastrointestinal: He has a history of diarrhea and has been colonized with yeast and pseudomonas in his urine and sputum cultures.
* Skin: He has anasarca and decubitus ulcers on his sacrum and left ear helix.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: He may require further weaning from the ventilator and may need to be transitioned to a different mode of ventilation.
* Cardiac complications: His elevated troponins may indicate ongoing myocardial ischemia or infarction, which could lead to cardiac arrest or arrhythmias.
* Adrenal insufficiency: He may require further cortisone therapy and monitoring to ensure that his adrenal function is adequate.
* Renal complications: His mild anemia and elevated troponins may indicate poor renal function, which could lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
* Gastrointestinal complications: He may require further management of his diarrhea and colonization with yeast and pseudomonas.
* Skin complications: He may require further wound care and management of his decubitus ulcers.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his underlying medical conditions to prevent complications and promote his recovery.

   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, felt he
   did not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to 0.61, Metoprolol
   was increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia.  Could have
   poor renal function without elevated creatinine in the setting of very
   little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs.
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile.  Has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine
   and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.  Lasix given overnight
   made slightly negative this AM.
   - Goal today is even to slightly negative with lasix prn.
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: Rehab as soon as bed available ?today

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, and chronic pleural effusion. He was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and was found to have adrenal insufficiency. He also has elevated troponins and is at risk for demand ischemia. He has a history of multiple complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and failure to wean from the ventilator.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.8°C (98.2°F)
* Heart rate: 98 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 115/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 30 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* SpO2: 97%

His lab results show:

* WBC: 10.4
* Hct: 29.5%
* Plt: 25
* Cr: 0.6
* TropT: 0.59
* TCO2: 34
* Glucose: 104 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 13.9/29.1/1.2, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 33/5/0.61, ALT/AST: 17/23, Alk Phos/T Bili: 179/0.5, Differential-Neuts: 60.4%, Lymph: 24.4%, Mono: 6.2%, Eos: 8.5%

Potential medical complications:

1. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency needs to be closely monitored and managed with cortisone replacement therapy.
2. Demand ischemia: The patient's elevated troponins and tachycardia suggest demand ischemia, which needs to be monitored and managed with medical therapy.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic COPD and respiratory failure require close monitoring and management with oxygen therapy and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).
4. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia needs to be managed with iron supplements and other nutritional support.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be due to colonization with yeast and pseudomonas, which needs to be monitored and managed with antibiotics if necessary.
6. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca (edema) needs to be managed with diuretics and other supportive measures.
7. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be due to adrenal insufficiency or medications, which needs to be monitored and managed with cortisone replacement therapy and minimization of unnecessary medications.
8. Pressure ulcers: The patient's pressure ulcers need to be managed with wound care and repositioning.
9. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder needs to be managed with close monitoring and replacement therapy.

Recommendations:

1. Continue cortisone replacement therapy for adrenal insufficiency.
2. Manage demand ischemia with medical therapy.
3. Continue oxygen therapy and NIPPV for respiratory failure.
4. Manage anemia with iron supplements and other nutritional support.
5. Monitor and manage leukocytosis with antibiotics if necessary.
6. Manage anasarca with diuretics and other supportive measures.
7. Monitor and manage eosinophilia with cortisone replacement therapy and minimization of unnecessary medications.
8. Manage pressure ulcers with wound care and repositioning.
9. Monitor and manage electrolyte and fluid disorder with close monitoring and replacement therapy.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, and chronic pleural effusion. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and was intubated due to failure to wean from the ventilator. The patient has been treated with antibiotics, but his troponins remain elevated, and he has been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency. He has also been experiencing anasarca, eosinophilia, and anemia.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.8°C
* Heart rate: 98 bpm
* Blood pressure: 115/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 30 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 97%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 10.4 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 25 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
* Troponin: 0.61 ng/mL
* Cortisol: 98 mg/dL
* ACTH: 31.1 pg/mL

The patient's medications include:

* Metoprolol 37.5 mg TID
* Prednisone 5 mg PO daily
* Furosemide 40 mg IV
* Heparin 5000 units SQ q12h
* Ranitidine 150 mg PO q8h

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic COPD and recent respiratory failure increase the risk of respiratory failure.
2. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may lead to hypotension, electrolyte imbalances, and adrenal crisis.
3. Anasarca: The patient's edema may worsen and lead to respiratory distress or cardiac complications.
4. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be a sign of allergic reaction or inflammation, which could lead to respiratory or cardiovascular complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen and lead to fatigue, shortness of breath, or decreased cardiac output.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to seizures, brain damage, or other neurological complications.
7. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's electrolyte and fluid disorder may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, or other complications.
8. Myocardial infarction: The patient's elevated troponins and cardiac history increase the risk of myocardial infarction.
9. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's decubitus ulcers may worsen and lead to infection, sepsis, or other complications.
10. Airway, inability to protect: The patient's tracheostomy and respiratory failure increase the risk of aspiration, respiratory failure, or other complications.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
   #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   -IP does not want to stent.  We will discuss this with his OSH
   pulmonologist.
   - He appears euvolemic on exam.  Goal yesterday was even, but patient
   was positive yesterday. Negative this AM.
   - wean from vent as much as possible.  Trial of trach mask went well.
   #. Seizure: One morning had what appeared to be a seizure since he was
   unresponsive and twitching.  No further episodes. EEG initial report
   shows no epileptiform activity, diffuse slowing consistent with
   encephalopathy .  If this recurs we could check a CT head.
   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, felt he
   did not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to 0.61, metoprolol
   was increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia.  Could have
   poor renal function without elevated creatinine in the setting of very
   little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Consult EP with possibility of slowing pacing to allow for more
   effective beta blockade.
   -Check troponin again and EKG
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   -If troponins trending up will get cardiology consult
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs.
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile.  Has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine
   and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.
   - Goal today is even to slightly negative with lasix prn.
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications (d/c
d antibiotics, PPI, diuretics,
   betablocker)
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and

   #Decreased albumin: Measuring prealbumin. Patient most likely

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, chronic pleural effusion, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with bronchiectasis. He was recently hospitalized for respiratory failure and was sent to the ICU for further management.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on ventilator support and is being weaned as much as possible. He had a trial of trach mask, which went well.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has elevated troponins, which are persistently elevated up to 0.61. He is being managed with metoprolol and is being monitored for possible demand ischemia.
* Adrenal: The patient has adrenal insufficiency, which was confirmed with a cortisotropin syn test. He is being treated with prednisone 5mg PO daily and is being monitored for cortisol levels.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which is thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency. He is being monitored for fever and has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, likely colonizers.
* Anasarca: The patient has anasarca, which is improving, although he still has UE>LE edema. An ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.
* Eosinophilia: The patient has eosinophilia, which is thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency. He is being monitored for eosinophilia and is being treated with prednisone.
* Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is thought to be due to chronic disease given his long hospital course. He is being monitored for anemia and is being treated with iron supplements.
* Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a right eye injection/macular orbital rash, which is thought to be due to blepharitis. He is being treated with bacitracin and vigamox.
* Decreased albumin: The patient has decreased albumin, which is thought to be due to chronic malnutrition. He is being monitored for albumin levels and is being treated with tube feeds via PEG tube.
* Ulcers: The patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx and stage IV ulcer on left ear helix. He is being treated with wound care and is being frequently repositioned.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and bronchiectasis put him at risk for respiratory failure, which could worsen with further respiratory distress.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and possible demand ischemia put him at risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
* Adrenal crisis: The patient's adrenal insufficiency puts him at risk for adrenal crisis, which could be triggered by stress or other factors.
* Leukopenia: The patient's leukocytosis could lead to leukopenia, which could increase his risk for infection.
* Anasarca: The patient's anasarca could worsen, leading to further fluid accumulation and respiratory distress.
* Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia could lead to eosinophilic pneumonia or other eosinophil-related complications.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen, leading to further fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
* Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient's right eye injection/macular orbital rash could worsen, leading to further eye discomfort and potentially even vision loss.
* Decreased albumin: The patient's decreased albumin could worsen, leading to further malnutrition and decreased albumin levels.
* Ulcers: The patient's ulcers could worsen, leading to further tissue damage and potentially even sepsis.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for a variety of medical complications, including respiratory failure, cardiac complications, adrenal crisis, leukopenia, anasarca, eosinophilia, anemia, right eye injection/macular orbital rash, decreased albumin, and ulcers. It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

1. Adrenal insufficiency (AI): The patient's history of chronic adrenal insufficiency and current laboratory results suggest that they may be at risk for adrenal crisis.
2. Edema: The patient's fluid balance is positive, which may lead to edema, especially in the peripheral regions.
3. Pneumonia: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and chronic respiratory failure may increase their risk of developing pneumonia.
4. Seizure: The patient's history of seizure disorder and current laboratory results suggest that they may be at risk for seizure activity.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, which may lead to hypernatremia and related complications.
6. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient's laboratory results suggest that they may have an electrolyte and fluid disorder, which may require further management.
7. Airway compromise: The patient's inability to protect their airway and history of respiratory failure may increase their risk of airway compromise.
8. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's history of impaired skin integrity and current laboratory results suggest that they may be at risk for skin breakdown and related complications.
9. Myocardial infarction: The patient's history of acute myocardial infarction and current laboratory results suggest that they may be at risk for further cardiac complications.

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and address these potential complications.

   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
   #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   Able to tolerate 6 hours on trache mask yesterday.
   - He appears euvolemic on exam.  Goal yesterday was negative 500mL, but
   patient was positive yesterday; as SBP 100-140, can give Lasix 40mg IV
   this morning and follow UOP
   - wean from vent
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs.
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.  Lasix given overnight
   made slightly negative this AM.
   - Goal today is negative as tolerated by blood pressure.
   -Give Lasix 40mg IV this morning and follow UOP.
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased ferritin.
   However, given more significant decrease today would like to guiaic
   stool and check reticulocyte count to ensure that bone marrow response
   appropriate.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   -Guiaic stool
   -Retic count
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile.  Has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine
   and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Patient's Condition:**

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with multiple complications, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), failure to wean from the ventilator, and tracheobronchomalacia.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Adrenal Insufficiency:** The patient has been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency, and the note recommends further evaluation and management with cortisone and prednisone.
2. **Anemia:** The patient has chronic anemia, and the note suggests that it may be due to anemia of chronic disease. Further evaluation with guaiac stool and reticulocyte count is recommended.
3. **Tachycardia:** The patient has persistent tachycardia, which may be related to demand ischemia or hypotension. Metoprolol has been increased to manage this condition.
4. **Leukocytosis:** The patient has leukocytosis, which may be due to colonizers or infection. No antibiotics are recommended at this time.
5. **Eosinophilia:** The patient has eosinophilia, which may be due to adrenal insufficiency or medications. Minimizing unnecessary medications and prednisone therapy are recommended.
6. **Right Eye Injection/Macular Orbital Rash:** The patient has a rash that is likely blepharitis, and the ophthalmologist has changed his drops to bacitracin and vigamox, which seems to be helping.
7. **Decubitus Ulcers:** The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers on his sacrum and ear, which require wound care and frequent repositioning.
8. **FEN (Tube Feeds):** The patient is receiving tube feeds via a PEG tube, with free water flushes every 4 hours.
9. **DVT Prophylaxis:** The patient is receiving heparin SQ and pneumatic boots for DVT prophylaxis.
10. **Ulcer Prophylaxis:** The patient is receiving ranitidine for ulcer prophylaxis.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue cortisone and prednisone therapy for adrenal insufficiency.
2. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider further evaluation with guaiac stool and reticulocyte count.
3. Continue metoprolol therapy to manage tachycardia.
4. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and consider further evaluation with antibiotics if necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's eosinophilia with prednisone therapy.
6. Continue wound care and frequent repositioning for the patient's decubitus ulcers.
7. Continue tube feeds via PEG tube with free water flushes every 4 hours.
8. Continue DVT and ulcer prophylaxis as recommended.

**Discharge Plan:**

The patient is planned for discharge to a rehabilitation facility as soon as a bed is available.

   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
   #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   - He appears euvolemic on exam.  Goal yesterday was negative 500mL, but
   patient was positive yesterday; as SBP 100-140, can give Lasix 40mg IV
   this morning and follow UOP
   - wean from vent as much as possible.  Trial of trach mask went well,
   but then needed some pressure support
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs.
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.  Lasix given overnight
   made slightly negative this AM.
   - Goal today is negative as tolerated by blood pressure.
   -Give Lasix 40mg IV this morning and follow UOP.
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased ferritin.
   However, given more significant decrease today would like to guiaic
   stool and check reticulocyte count to ensure that bone marrow response
   appropriate.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   -Guiaic stool
   -Retic count
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile.  Has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine
   and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: Rehab as soon as bed available ?today

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), tracheostomy, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube and is receiving oxygen therapy. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 98%.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has elevated troponins, indicating myocardial infarction, but no cardiac catheterization was performed. He is being managed medically with metoprolol.
* Hematological: The patient has anemia, likely due to chronic disease, and is being monitored with daily hematocrit and reticulocyte count.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a PEG tube for nutrition and is receiving fiber source for bowel management. He has a history of diarrhea and has had negative cultures for Clostridium difficile.
* Skin: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers on his sacrum and ear, respectively, which are being managed with wound care and frequent repositioning.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's COPD and tracheostomy placement increase his risk of respiratory failure, particularly if he experiences an exacerbation or develops a respiratory infection.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponins and history of myocardial infarction make him at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of anemia and diarrhea increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly if he develops a bleeding ulcer or has a gastrointestinal infection.
* Skin breakdown: The patient's decubitus ulcers are at risk of progressing to deeper stages, which can lead to increased morbidity and mortality.
* Infection: The patient's history of pneumonia and sepsis increase his risk of developing another infection, particularly if he has a central line or other invasive devices.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency requires ongoing monitoring and management to prevent adrenal crisis.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning from mechanical ventilation as much as possible
* Managing his respiratory status with oxygen therapy and bronchodilators
* Monitoring his cardiovascular status with frequent vital signs and echocardiograms
* Managing his gastrointestinal status with fiber source and bowel management
* Monitoring his skin status with frequent wound care and repositioning
* Managing his anemia with iron supplements and reticulocyte count monitoring
* Monitoring his electrolyte and fluid status with frequent laboratory tests and adjusting his medication regimen as needed.

 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
   #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean from
   ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.
   - He appears euvolemic on exam.  Goal yesterday was negative 500mL, but
   patient was positive yesterday; as SBP 100-140, can give Lasix 40mg IV
   this morning and follow UOP
   - wean from vent as much as possible.  Trial of trach mask went well,
   but then needed some pressure support
   #. Elevated troponins: No CP; cardiology saw him on arrival, felt he
   did not require emergent cardiac catheterization, recommend medical
   management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of tachycardia and
   hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to 0.61, Metoprolol
   was increased out of concern for likely demand ischemia.  Could have
   poor renal function without elevated creatinine in the setting of very
   little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 37.5 TID
   #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs.
   -Prednisone 5mg PO daily
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile.  Has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine
   and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.  Lasix given overnight
   made slightly negative this AM.
   - Goal today is negative as tolerated by blood pressure.
   -Give Lasix 40mg IV this morning and follow UOP.
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Anemia: Hct stable, likely anemia of chronic disease given long
   hospital course; iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and
   increased ferritin. HCT decreased today again. Guiaic stool. Hemolysis
   labs.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for possible stenting of tracheobronchomalacia. The patient has a complex medical condition with multiple comorbidities, including:

1. Adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease): The patient has been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency, and treatment includes prednisone 5mg PO daily.
2. Eosinophilia: The patient has elevated eosinophil counts, which may be secondary to adrenal insufficiency or medications.
3. Anemia: The patient has a chronic anemia, likely due to anemia of chronic disease, with stable hemoglobin levels.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient has a mild leukocytosis, likely due to colonization with yeast and pseudomonas.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient has elevated sodium levels, which may be due to fluid overload or electrolyte imbalance.
6. Electrolyte and fluid disorder: The patient has an electrolyte imbalance, with elevated sodium and potassium levels.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient has chronic respiratory failure, with a history of COPD and bronchiectasis.
8. Myocardial infarction: The patient has had an acute myocardial infarction, with elevated troponin levels.
9. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has pressure ulcers on the sacrum/coccyx and left ear helix.
10. Airway, inability to protect: The patient has a tracheostomy tube in place, and there is a risk of aspiration.

The patient's current medications include:

* Ranitidine (prophylaxis)
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Metoprolol 37.5 TID
* Prednisone 5mg PO daily

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning from the ventilator as much as possible
* Trial of tracheostomy mask
* Continue ASA and metoprolol
* Continue corticosteroid therapy for adrenal insufficiency
* Monitor for fever and leukocytosis
* Minimize unnecessary medications
* Daily hemoglobin checks and active transfusion service
* Wound care and frequent repositioning for pressure ulcers
* Tube feeds via PEG tube with free water flushes
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or myocardial infarction
* Infection, particularly pneumonia or sepsis
* Electrolyte imbalance or fluid overload
* Pressure ulcer progression
* Airway complications, such as aspiration or tracheostomy tube displacement
* Adrenal crisis due to inadequate treatment of adrenal insufficiency
* Anemia worsening
* Eosinophilia worsening
* Hypernatremia worsening

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, and a recent hospitalization at OSH with multiple complications.

The patient is currently in the ICU with a tracheostomy and PEG tube in place. He is receiving mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 101 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 102/57 mmHg.

The patient has several potential medical complications that require close monitoring:

1. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisotropin syn test was positive for adrenal insufficiency, and he is receiving 250mcg Cosyntropin every 30 minutes. His ACTH, cortisol, and PRA levels will be monitored.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease, and his iron studies are consistent with this diagnosis. However, his recent decrease in HCT requires further evaluation, including guaiac stool and reticulocyte count.
3. Tachycardia: The patient's elevated troponins are concerning for possible demand ischemia, and he is receiving metoprolol to manage this condition.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and he has had yeast and pseudomonas on his urine and sputum cultures. However, these are likely colonizers, and he is not receiving antibiotics at this time.
5. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia is thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency, but it may also be secondary to medications. He is receiving prednisone for adrenal insufficiency.
6. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a likely case of blepharitis, and his pilocarpine drops may have worsened his discomfort. He is now receiving bacitracin and vigamox drops.
7. Ulcers: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers on his sacrum and ear, respectively. He is receiving wound care and frequent repositioning to prevent further damage.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Weaning from mechanical ventilation
2. Monitoring of adrenal insufficiency and anemia
3. Management of tachycardia and possible demand ischemia
4. Monitoring of leukocytosis and eosinophilia
5. Wound care and management of ulcers
6. Nutrition and glycemic control
7. Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's disposition is planned for rehabilitation as soon as a bed becomes available.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), tracheobronchomalacia, and adrenal insufficiency. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation, and has been experiencing chronic anemia, leukocytosis, and eosinophilia. He has also had episodes of hypernatremia, electrolyte and fluid disorders, and impaired skin integrity.

The patient's recent medical events include a cardiac catheterization, which revealed no significant coronary artery disease. He has been experiencing tachycardia, elevated troponins, and hypotension, which may be related to demand ischemia. He has also had a recent episode of sepsis, which was treated with antibiotics.

The patient's current medications include metoprolol, ASA, and prednisone, and he is receiving tube feeds via PEG tube. He has a PICC line and an arterial line, and is being monitored for DVT and stress ulcers.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency is being managed with cortisone therapy, but he may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent adrenal crisis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is being managed with mechanical ventilation, but he may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent further deterioration.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease, but he may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent further anemia.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be due to infection or inflammation, and he may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent further complications.
5. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be due to adrenal insufficiency or medications, and he may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent further complications.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may be due to electrolyte and fluid disorders, and he may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent further complications.
7. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity may be due to his medical condition, and he may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent further complications.
8. Infection: The patient has had recent episodes of infection, including sepsis, and may require further treatment and monitoring to prevent further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's adrenal function and adjust cortisone therapy as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and adjust as necessary.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's leukocytosis and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's eosinophilia and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hypernatremia and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's impaired skin integrity and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient for infection and adjust treatment as necessary.

ICU Care:

1. Nutrition: The patient is receiving tube feeds via PEG tube and should continue to receive adequate nutrition.
2. Glycemic control: The patient's blood glucose levels should be monitored and adjusted as necessary to prevent hyperglycemia.
3. Lines: The patient has a PICC line and an arterial line, which should be monitored and maintained as necessary.
4. Prophylaxis: The patient should receive prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcers, and VAP as necessary.
5. Communication: The patient's family should be updated regularly on his condition and treatment plan.

   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.  Has
   been tolerating trach mask well
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs.

   base with Endocrine about this dosage
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.
   --Goal today is negative as blood pressure can tolerate
   --Is only slightly negative through [**Location 11298**] 40mg IV bid
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased ferritin.
   However, given more significant decrease today would like to guiaic
   stool and check reticulocyte count to ensure that bone marrow response
   appropriate.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA

   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile.  Has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine
   and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's health status and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Current Health Status:**

* The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), tracheobronchomalacia, and chronic anemia.
* He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure, adrenal insufficiency, and other comorbidities.
* His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 101 beats per minute, blood pressure of 102/57 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute.
* He is receiving oxygen therapy through a tracheostomy tube and is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and pressure support ventilation (PSV).
* His laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating possible cardiac ischemia, and his electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Adrenal Insufficiency:** The patient's corticotropin stimulation test is positive for adrenal insufficiency, which may lead to hypotension, electrolyte imbalances, and cardiovascular instability.
2. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient's chronic COPD and tracheobronchomalacia may lead to respiratory failure, especially if his ventilation settings are not optimized.
3. **Cardiac Ischemia:** The patient's elevated troponin levels and tachycardia may indicate cardiac ischemia, which can lead to myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
4. **Anemia:** The patient's chronic anemia may worsen if his bone marrow response is inadequate, leading to fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased exercise tolerance.
5. **Electrolyte Imbalance:** The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but his adrenal insufficiency and cardiac ischemia may lead to electrolyte imbalances, such as hypokalemia or hyperkalemia.
6. **Wound Infections:** The patient's stage III and IV decubitus ulcers on his sacrum/coccyx and left ear helix may become infected, leading to sepsis and systemic complications.
7. **Pneumonia:** The patient's chronic COPD and tracheobronchomalacia may increase his risk of developing pneumonia, especially if his ventilation settings are not optimized.
8. **Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT):** The patient's prophylactic DVT ppx with heparin SQ and pneumatic boots may not be sufficient to prevent DVT, especially if his mobility is limited.

**Plan of Care:**

1. Continue to optimize the patient's ventilation settings to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely, including his troponin levels, and adjust his medication regimen as necessary.
3. Manage the patient's adrenal insufficiency with cortisone replacement therapy and monitor his electrolyte levels closely.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and consider transfusions if necessary.
5. Ensure proper wound care and monitoring of the patient's decubitus ulcers to prevent infection.
6. Consider antibiotic prophylaxis for the patient's tracheostomy tube and PEG tube to prevent infection.
7. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent electrolyte imbalances.
8. Consider consults with cardiology, pulmonology, and endocrinology to optimize the patient's care.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, and chronic pleural effusion. He has been admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, adrenal insufficiency, and hypernatremia. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 30%.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 105/58 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 24 inspirations per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98%. His weight has decreased from 67 kg to 62.1 kg since admission.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating possible demand ischemia. His eosinophil count is elevated, which may be due to adrenal insufficiency or medications. His anemia is likely due to chronic disease, and his iron studies are consistent with this diagnosis.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient has a cortisotropin syn test positive for adrenal insufficiency. He is currently receiving prednisone 5mg PO daily, but the dose needs to be adjusted.
2. Anasarca: The patient has peripheral edema, which is improving with diuresis.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease, and his iron studies are consistent with this diagnosis.
4. Tachycardia: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, indicating possible demand ischemia.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient has a white blood cell count of 10.1 x 10^9/L, which is elevated. He has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine and sputum cultures, but these are likely colonizers.
6. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophil count is elevated, which may be due to adrenal insufficiency or medications.
7. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient has a rash that is likely due to blepharitis.
8. Ulcers: The patient has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers on his sacrum/coccyx and left ear helix, respectively.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his COPD exacerbates.
2. Adrenal crisis: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may lead to an adrenal crisis if not properly managed.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly managed.
4. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia may lead to cardiac complications if not properly managed.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may lead to infection if not properly managed.
6. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may lead to allergic reactions if not properly managed.
7. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: The patient's rash may worsen if not properly managed.
8. Ulcers: The patient's ulcers may worsen if not properly managed.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue weaning from the ventilator.
2. Manage the patient's adrenal insufficiency with prednisone and close monitoring.
3. Manage the patient's anasarca with diuresis and close monitoring.
4. Manage the patient's anemia with iron studies and close monitoring.
5. Manage the patient's tachycardia with metoprolol and close monitoring.
6. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and eosinophilia closely.
7. Manage the patient's right eye injection/macular orbital rash with antibiotics and close monitoring.
8. Manage the patient's ulcers with wound care and close monitoring.

The patient's disposition is planned for rehabilitation as soon as a bed becomes available.

* The patient is a 80-year-old male with a significant past medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), chronic anemia, and a recent hospitalization at OSH with multiple complications.
* He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory failure, adrenal insufficiency, and other comorbidities.
* His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 98 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 105/58 mmHg.
* He is receiving oxygen therapy through a tracheostomy tube and is on a ventilator with a CPAP/PSV mode.
* His laboratory results show anemia, elevated troponin levels, and eosinophilia, which may be related to adrenal insufficiency, medications, or other underlying conditions.
* He has stage III and IV decubitus ulcers on his sacrum and left ear helix, respectively, and is receiving wound care and frequent repositioning.
* He is also experiencing peripheral edema, which is being managed with diuretics.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic COPD and recent hospitalization may increase his risk of respiratory failure.
* Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's corticotropin stimulation test was positive for adrenal insufficiency, and he is receiving treatment with prednisone. However, he may require further evaluation and management to ensure adequate adrenal function.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia may be related to chronic disease, and he may require further evaluation and treatment to address this condition.
* Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia may be related to adrenal insufficiency, medications, or other underlying conditions, and he may require further evaluation and management to address this condition.
* Decubitus ulcers: The patient's stage III and IV decubitus ulcers may increase his risk of infection and further complications if not properly managed.
* Peripheral edema: The patient's peripheral edema may increase his risk of further complications, such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism, if not properly managed.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, I recommend the following:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to ensure that his condition is stable and improving.
* Continue to manage his respiratory failure with oxygen therapy and ventilator support.
* Continue to manage his adrenal insufficiency with prednisone and further evaluation and management as needed.
* Continue to manage his anemia with iron studies and further evaluation and treatment as needed.
* Continue to manage his eosinophilia with minimization of unnecessary medications and further evaluation and management as needed.
* Continue to manage his decubitus ulcers with wound care and frequent repositioning.
* Continue to manage his peripheral edema with diuretics and further evaluation and management as needed.

I also recommend that the patient's primary contact person, his daughter, be informed of his current condition and treatment plan, and that she be involved in his care and decision-making process as needed.

Summary:

The patient is an 80-year-old male with a significant medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), who was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for assessment and management of multiple complications. He has a tracheostomy and is currently on mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 30%. The patient has been diagnosed with adrenal insufficiency, anemia, and tachycardia, and is being managed with medications such as prednisone, metoprolol, and aspirin.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 105/58 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98% on a tracheostomy tube.

The patient has a chronic pleural effusion and chronic bronchiectasis, and has been experiencing respiratory failure. He has also been diagnosed with anemia, likely due to chronic disease, and is being managed with iron studies and transfusions as needed.

The patient has a history of diarrhea, and has been treated with antibiotics in the past. He has also been experiencing eosinophilia, which is thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency, but is still being monitored.

The patient has several skin lesions, including a macular orbital rash, and has been diagnosed with decubitus ulcers on his sacrum and left ear helix. He is being managed with wound care and frequent repositioning.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and respiratory failure could lead to further complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory acidosis.
2. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency could lead to further complications, such as hypotension, electrolyte imbalances, and adrenal crisis.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia could lead to further complications, such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased tolerance to stress.
4. Eosinophilia: The patient's eosinophilia could lead to further complications, such as allergic reactions, asthma, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
5. Skin lesions: The patient's skin lesions could lead to further complications, such as infection, necrosis, and scarring.
6. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's decubitus ulcers could lead to further complications, such as infection, sepsis, and prolonged hospitalization.
7. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension could lead to further complications, such as cardiac disease, stroke, and kidney disease.
8. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia could lead to further complications, such as dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and seizures.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and manage his complications aggressively to prevent further deterioration.

 ADRENAL INSUFFICIENCY (AI, ADDISON, ADDISON'S)
 EDEMA, PERIPHERAL
 PLEURAL EFFUSION, CHRONIC
 ANEMIA, CHRONIC
 RASH
 CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE (COPD, BRONCHITIS, EMPHYSEMA)
   WITHOUT ACUTE EXACERBATION
 SEIZURE, WITHOUT STATUS EPILEPTICUS
 HYPERNATREMIA (HIGH SODIUM)
 ELECTROLYTE & FLUID DISORDER, OTHER
 .H/O RESPIRATORY FAILURE, CHRONIC
 ALTERATION IN NUTRITION
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)

 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   80M with PMHx significant for COPD, s/p long hospital course at OSH
   with multiple complications, including VAP, failure to wean from
   ventilator, s/p trach and PEG placement, sent from OSH for IP
   assessment for possible stenting of ?tracheobronchomalacia.
    #. Respiratory Failure: H/o COPD and s/p trach for failure to wean
   from ventilator also with bronchiectasis.  CT here showed only findings
   suggestive of infection and no TBM.  Per family report, patient using
   home O2 for less than one month prior to going to hospital, seems he
   was not that limited by COPD prior to most recent hospitalization.  Has
   been tolerating trach mask well
   -Will continue to wean from vent, currently on PSV 5/5 with 30% FiO2.
    #Adrenal insufficiency: Cortisotropin syn test + for adrenal
   insufficiency. Per Endocrine recs, got baseline morning ACTH, cortisol,
   PRA, [**Male First Name (un) **], then give 250mcg Cosyntropin, then the same labs at 30 and
   60 mins. Will f/u these labs.
   - Continues on Prednisone 5mg PO daily for now but will need to touch
   base with Endocrine about this dosage
   -Will need outpatient appointment for F/u with Endocrine, outpatient
   pulmonologist aware, will include in d/c summary as well.
   #. Anasarca: Improved, though he continues to have UE>LE edema.  An
   ultrasound was negative for an obstructive clot.
   --Goal today is negative as blood pressure can tolerate
   --Is only slightly negative through [**Location 11298**] 40mg IV bid
   #. Anemia: Likely anemia of chronic disease given long hospital course;
   iron studies consistent, with decreased TIBC and increased ferritin.
   -Retic index 1.17 indicating hypoproliferation.
   -Daily HCT, minimize unecassary lab draws
   -Active T&S.
   # Tachycardic: Elevated troponins, no CP; cardiology saw him on
   arrival, felt he did not require emergent cardiac catheterization,
   recommend medical management. Possible demand ischemia, in setting of
   tachycardia and hypotension.   Troponin is persistently elevated up to
   0.61.  Metoprolol was increased out of concern for likely demand
   ischemia.  Could have poor renal function without elevated creatinine
   in the setting of very little muscle mass.
   -Continue ASA
   -Continue Metoprolol 25mg PO q6
   #. Leukocytosis: Now afebrile.  Has had yeast and pseudomonas on urine
   and sputum cultures, likely colonizers. Patient also has significant
   history of diarrhea, C. diff neg.  Central line from OSH now pulled, no
   growth to date.
   - No antibiotics for now.
   -Monitor fever curve
   #. Eosinophilia: Thought to be due to adrenal insufficiency; however,
   still continues to be elevated. [**Month (only) 51**] be secondary to medications.
   -Minimize unecassary medications
   -Prednisone as above for adrenal insufficiency
   #. Right eye injection/macular orbital rash: Seen by ophtho who said
   that this is likely blepharitis and that the pilocarpine may have been
   worsening his discomfort.  They changed his drops to bacitracin and
   vigamox which seems to be helping.
   #Ulcers: Patient has stage III decubitus ulcer on sacrum/coccyx with
   minimal amount of serous drainage, and Stage IV ulcer on left ear helix
   with very scant amount of serous drainage. Patient also has circular
   healed pressure ulcer to right post acromium process. All present on
   arrival to [**Hospital1 19**].   Wound care is following and he is being frequently
   repositioned.
   #. FEN: Tube feeds via PEG tube, free water flushes 250 cc q4
   #. PPX:
   -DVT ppx with: Heparin SQ and pneumoboots.
   -Bowel regimen PRN
   -Ulcer ppx with ranitidine.
   #. ACCESS: PICC
   #. CODE STATUS: No right heart cath, full code.
   #. EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] is married, however wife not [**Name2 (NI) 2681**]
   speaking; patient's sister suggests patient's daughter [**Name (NI) 11128**] should be
   primary contact person, lives with mother and aware of wishes.
   #. DISPOSITION: Rehab as soon as bed available ?today
